Kind of a weird/sad memory. But I recall during 9/11 when I got sent home from school early, I had no idea what was going on but my father's girlfriend had the TV on the news and I got into an argument with her about house rules of: No TV on the weekdays.
Lol
Funny and sad
She was a bit of a crazy bitch, and we really didn't get along besides, but I do feel a bit bad about it now.
I remember hearing about it at school, but I had no idea what it meant at the time
Same. No one told the kids what was going on. I remember the teacher getting a phone call, and then we were just all sent home for seemingly no reason.
I think 9/11 is a fairly important thing to know about.. rules be damned
it's news
Didn't want the kids to panic at school I guess with a "We're under attack" announcement.
it's not like you're wasting time watching something when you should be doin homework or whatever

not the school thing

loootta ppl died that day

Around 3000 iirc.
I was in kindergarten I think
Mrs. Blaylock's 5th grade class.
We all sat in the hall (almost tornado drill style) till teacher comes to collect us one by one after they verify each parent-to-child relationship claimed is accurate
6th grade class here
I remember it was a day we were allowed to chew gum as a class reward for something.
Teachers whispering to each other
What I remember is that my dad showed up with my mom. Despite my mom always being the one to pick us up from school every day, he decided to come with that day
Mrs. Blaylock had us all play Heads Up 7 Up and Silent Ball until the busses arrived.
If I remember right
Things were a little crazy here, because this is a military base town.
Wow I never knew there were such big reactions in schools
All the teachers were whispering to each other, everything was quiet and the school basically went into lockdown
I just remember the teach from across the hall come over and say turn on the TV, "A plane struck a tower in new york."
I saw the second plane hit the tower, live on TV.
They evacuated for great of another attack. On a school or something similar so evacuations were put out
*fear
We were on lockdown for a bit, before they called the busses, and let parents start picking their kids up.

Well, I mean, when the Pentagon, literally one of the biggest icons of the military and Department of Defense is blown the fuck up, people get really upset about the possibility of it being more than a single attack.
I don‚Äôt even remember them allowing busses to run
All parents were called for an emergency pick up. And you had to be on the approved to pick up child list
I didn't know about the Pentagon until after I got home and basically sitting in front of the TV watching the news all day.
I remember before I got off the bus that morning. Two really big military choppers flew right over the school very very low. "Probably less than 100 feet."
We never see military choppers around here, even being an Air Force Base.
We only really see the big C-130s and the like.
I‚Äôm surprised there wasn‚Äôt a panic when all the cryptic quiet stuff started with the adults. They weren‚Äôt answering questions other than ‚Äúmommy and daddy are coming to get you‚Äù stuff
oof weird
They didn't tell us much. Being 6th grade, we knew shit was going wrong.
My dad was paying attention to the military part of it
Like, we are on lockdown, once we get the go ahead you can be picked up by you parents or ride the bus home.
Pretty sure there was a wonder if they‚Äôd try contacting him even after his retirement
Then later that evening, after the eerie silence that haunted that day.
My mom had some semblance of normality. I told her how the day had gone for me, and she acted like this was just an odd random thing
That whole day was very silent.
Then about early evening there was a loud BANG that rattled people's windows, and knocked stuff off shelves.
a plane broke the sound barrier over our area.
Scared the ever loving shit out of people.
I remember just about every little thing that happened that day.
